column2: meaning "I rule") is a form of government in which two individuals ("diarchs") are joint heads of state. Most diarchs hold their position for life
column3: passing the position to their children or other family members.Diarchy is one of the oldest forms of government: examples include ancient Sparta
column5: Carthage as well Germanic and Dacian tribes. Several ancient Polynesian societies also exhibited a diarchic political structure. Ranks in the Inca Empire were structured in moieties
column6: with two occupants of each rank
column8: one hanan (upper) and one hurin (lower). In modern usage
column9: diarchy means a system of dual rule
column10: whether this be of a government or of an organization. Such 'diarchies' are not hereditary.Modern examples of diarchies are the Principality of Andorra
column11: whose heads of state are the President of France and the Bishop of Urgell; the Republic of San Marino
column12: led by two collegial Captains Regent; and the Kingdom of Swaziland
column13: where the joint heads of state are the King and his mother.
